lines.text: [Lucky is looking out of a car window]
Oh, I'm so dizzy. All I see is line, line, line line.
So look somewhere else.
Okay. Tree, tree, tree tree.
You know how to do CPR?
CPR? I can't even spell it!

[John plays rehab counselor to an alcoholic monkey from the circus]
... The problem with your equilibrium might be due to an inner ear infection...
[the monkey grunts, belches, and produces a small empty bottle]
... Or it may be due to THIS.
I'm a social drinker. Ha ha.
[grunts]
Very social. Ha ha.
[belches]
I think you're wasted. Nobody likes a drunk monkey.

[on telephone]
Hey, honey, feeling better?
Who's this?
I'm cute, I'm furry, and I make five hundred babies a year!
Rodney. Get back in your cage.
What's up with that trap behind the fridge? You trying to kill me?
Never mind that. Get your little furry ass back in your cage. Now. I don't want your droppings on... Bye-bye.
[to security guard]
My son Rodney. Little hairy boy, sleeps in the cage. I have to keep him in the cage because he has hygiene problems.
...Just like his dad wanted, John Dolittle grew up to be a normal and regular guy - you know, miserable.

[John emerges from his apartment to get his newspaper; he notices a stray puppy in the hallway]
Hey, get out of here!
[the puppy wimpers and takes a squirt right there in the hallway. John yells inside]
Hey, there's a vicious animal in the hallway!

[driving back to San Francisco from his father's home]
... Hi, Sam! I was just on my way into town; I wondered if you might want to get together for a drink or a CAT scan or something.
00 in the morning. Can't it wait until dawn?

[John pulls up alongside another car; the huge, sad-looking dog in its passenger-seat looks over at him]
... *I LOVE YOU.*
...No it can't, Sam. I have to come over right now.
What's he doing with that?
You don't want to know.
Just don't let him stick that thing up my... HELLO!
[after performing CPR on a rat, the rat farts]
He just had gas
Whoa! you're telling me!
A little girl once called me "Please mommy, not him."
John, do me a favor. Don't ever confide in me. I'm utterly useless in these areas. I'm really a very self-absorbed man.
Ooh, man - you scared the crap out of me. See? There it is.

[to a 26-year-old intern who has summoned him to the hospital at 2 AM to deal with a difficult patient]
... You spend all your time here, right? Probably grab your naps curled up in the break room; Little occasional nookie with one of the interns in the closet. But I have a real life, and I'd appreciate it if you only call me down here when there's a REAL emergency. If one of my patients comes in carrying his own head, call me. If somebody comes in with a bicycle halfway up their ass, call me.

[John has just been talking to an owl when Lisa joins him outside]
Oh, my goodness - It's an owl.
Yeah - it's a big, nasty owl. Let's go in.
It's beautiful.
they can poke your eye out; take your finger off very easily... all of that.

[upon entering the doctor's house]
Beep, beep, we're the sheep!
I didn't say you were crazy, you're special, and crazy, a lot of great people in history were crazy.
Like who?

Some of the greatest people in history. Albert Einstein, he came in with that wild hair and everybody thought he was crazy. And Muhammad Ali, he came out saying what rounds he was going to beat people in, going "I'm the greatest!", everybody thought he was crazy. And Joan of Arc, she heard voices.
Like you, Daddy?

[when Lucky comes to see him at the Hammerstein Retreat]
What are you doing here?
You're unbelievable. I cross three parkways at night, no less, to come to rescue you, and all I get is "What are you doing here?"
This isn't a prison, it's a clinic.
Look, the tiger's in bad shape.

The tiger? Hey, listen, forget the tiger! Let me tell you something. I had a perfect life until you came along and started talkin' to me. Now I'm sittin' in a robe and slippers discussin' "Mister Ed" with these guys. You've ruined my life enough. I don't wanna talk to you anymore. Just get outta here, please? Go! This is crazy!
now it's crazy to wanna save a tiger's life.
Look, tigers die everyday. It's called nature.

Well, let me tell you a little something about nature. I'm a dog, and I act like a dog. I don't try to be anybody else. We are who we are, and you are a doctor who can talk to animals. That's who you are.

[defensive]
That is not who I am!
Stop lying to yourself!

[his anger rising by the second]
Didn't I tell you to get outta here? Get outta here! Go! Get outta here!

[preparing to leave]
Fine.
Quit comin' around and talkin' to me!

[looking over his shoulder]
With pleasure!
YOU BETTER NOT COME BACK! AAAGH!
Bonehead.
[goes on his way]

[shouting to no animal in particular]
THAT MEANS ALL OF Y'ALL! LEAVE ME ALONE! STOP TALKIN' TO ME!
Ruined his life. That's a laugh.
AAAGH! AAAAAAAAAGH! AAAAAAAAGH!
[after he finishes shouting, he goes back inside where the two other guys are standing there confused]
AAAAGH!

[Her pet guinea pig is missing]
Dad, you HAVE to find Rodney.
Sure, I'll find your rat.
He's a guinea pig.
Whatever; they're both rodents. I'll find your rodent; I'll put down some of that sticky paper for him.
No, not that!
It'll be fine; you peel him right off it, and he'll live.

[atop an observatory]
... And now, on the day I end it all, I'd like to leave Margaret the bearded lady my rhinestone collar and my wet-dry shaver. I'd like to leave Jack the midget nothing. It's too late for you, Jack. You're a short...
[John's Range-Rover pulls up at the main entrance, far below. With John are Lucky and both of the Rats]
... Hey, get out of there! You're in my landing space!

[from the Range-Rover]
See if you land on your feet, Road-Kill.

[following John up to confront the tiger]
... Coming right up - one order of man, side of dog.
Good-bye, cruel world. Oh no, I just remembered. I wanted to leave the whip to the baboon. One of the few animals which enjoy that kind of thing.

[attempts to talk the tiger out of jumping from the observatory]
Hey, whoa. Take it easy now... Remember that song "Eye of the Tiger," from ROCKY 3? When Rocky was fighting Mr. T, couldn't beat him - then Apollo Creed played "Eye of the Tiger" for him. Rocky beat the snot out of Mr. T because of "Eye of the Tiger." Because that song moved Rocky inside...
[He sings the song, way out of tune, to demonstrate]
... Not Eye of the Moose, not Eye of the Bull, Eye of the TIGER.
That's it. I'm jumping.
Listen, I'm a doctor. Maybe I can help you. If I can't, then you can eat me AND Lucky.
Or just him.
All right. I just hope you're a better doctor than you are a singer.
Good job, Doc. Although, seeing a tiger jump 5 stories would have been really cool.
I heard that.
...John, Gene has got qualms about the new proposal.
I'm worried that, if we let a big company like Calnet take us over, we're not gonna be us anymore. We'd be - THEM.
THEM has the best hospitals and laboratories; and THEM is gonna pay us a very big, giant amount of money.
When I think about the money, I get teary... Saturday morning, we're meeting the Calnet people.
Whoa. I'm supposed to take my family to the country this weekend.
Well, don't.
you're being forced to neglect your family.
Gene, relax. No such thing. OK, Saturday morning. And Gene - no tank tops, please.
...Your daughter's turning into a little wise-ass.
Worse. She's turning into a little YOU.
...There's more to this HMO deal than money. You sell, they own you.
Lisa, this is gonna be good for us.
I'm so tired of that rap. It's always for US, but sometimes I don't know who US *IS!*

[John has bought Lisa a fancy new sports car]
Oh, my God! John, you didn't!
No, I didn't. The van's around the corner. But don't tell me you don't care about money.
...Bagel chips!
Back off, or you'll find your nuts in a tree!
Ow! Where's the love?
talking to myself; with dirt under my fingernails; stinking; with my hair all matted. It's not a cool look.

[Rodney's cage is strapped to the top of John's Range-Rover, which is cruising down the highway]
... Come on, Doc! I'm getting whisker-whipped up here! Hey - this is cruel to animals!
One more word, and I'm letting you out! I'll leave you in the wild! With the REAL animals! See how much talk you do when squirrels are kickin' your ass in!
Fine, then I'll just sing!
[proceeds to sing Bob Dylan's "Blowin' In the Wind," way out of tune]
..."The answer, my friend, is blowin' in the wind..."
SHUT UP!
[turns the radio way up]

[singing]
... This guinea pig is blowin' in the wind!
I can't hear you! I'm groovin'!
...Why do they call me "guinea pig," anyway? I'm not Italian, and I'm not pork...!
SHUT UP, I SAID!
Grandpa, did Daddy learn how to be bossy from you?
He certainly didn't learn it from his mother, God rest her soul.
[John's Range-Rover drives up, with Rodney's cage strapped to the roof]
Daddy, what's Rodney doing on the roof?
I thought the fresh air would do him good.
Lunatic! Crazy man! Psycho!

[looks at Rodney murderously]
... Daddy, we still got those BB guns I used to play with when I was little?

[In the middle of the night, John goes into his father's kitchen to get a drink of water... and promptly regrets it]
... Can I make a request? Tuna in OIL instead of WATER?
Hey, who put in that bug-zapper?
[John charges outside]
Yo, looky here. Hey, buddy. My old lady asks, I been eating trash all night. You dig?
[John accidentally steps on a Skunk]
Yah! You're on my tail, you idiot... You broke Mr. Stinky, I think.
[John flees to his Range-Rover]
Doc, while you're out, get some salmon. You can't go wrong with salmon.

[John has just arrived at the home of his old friend, Sam Litvack, for a CAT scan]
... What's your problem?
Your face.
I'll hit you so hard, you'll see 10 more of me.
It already SMELLS like 10 more of you. So just bring it on, cheese-eater... Hey, you gerbil!

[They both notice John staring at them for the first time]
... What are YOU looking at?
I'm just looking at a couple of greasy rats fighting over some garbage.
Come HERE and say that, you 4-eyed bubble-headed doofus biped! I'll get bubonic on your ass!
What if I take that light bulb there, and put it between your little rat butt cheeks, and make a little rodent lamp out of you?
[notices that Sam Litvack has joined him]
... I'm sorry, Sam; how are you?

[John has been admitted to the "retreat" of his old medical school-nemesis, Blain]
... John Dolittle. Who would have ever thought YOU would end up in a mental institution? Number one in our medical school class. Not that I'm jealous, John. Someone had to finish first.
Someone had to finish last, too.
So, John... You talk to animals now, do you? Would you like to tell me about it? Or would you rather tell my friend here - Bettelheim?
I don't need to talk to your cat, Blain.
Why, do you think he would talk back to you?
He just might.
And what would he say?
I'd say Blain Hammersmith was a butthead.
I really like this cat.

[Jake the Tiger is about to be taken, by John and Lucky, to the hospital for an operation]
... Wait a minute. The dog gets to ride up front?
Stop looking at me like I'm a side dish.
Don't flatter yourself.

[to Lisa and Maya, the latter of whom has resolved to give up her experiments and be more like John]
... John's always been able to talk with animals. I used to think it was a handicap, but it's not; it's a gift. Sometimes, daddies are the ones who need to change.

[to Lucky]
... You are NOT my pet. I wouldn't get one as annoying as you.

[Lucky has conned John into taking him to Camp Hawkeye as a pet for Kyla]
... Does he do any tricks?
He does a neat trick with a thermometer that's funny.
...This should take care of the inflammation. The only problem is, who'll wipe it on for you?
Does Brad Pitt need a goat?

[Lucky walks in on an intimate moment between John and Lisa]
... Oh, Mrs. Dolittle...!
Yeah, baby!

[to Lisa]
Excuse me just one second, OK?
[to Lucky]
Let's go.
What a gyp.
You mind if I have a little privacy, please?
But it's fine when people watch us dogs do it, huh?
[John shuts the door on him; he continues]
... Fine to turn on the garden hose. Hey, you want a tip on a good position...?

[Various animals are pouring into John's apartment]
... Good evening, Doctor.
...No. You're gonna have to take your fat ass back out.
Oh, my God. What a zoo.
Hmm, obviously not a kosher establishment.
Where are the chicks? Ooh! I'm cool.

[belches]
... Very well-appointed sty.
What's going on? What is all this?
I don't know. You know, tell a friend. Ha ha.
Looks like they need to talk to a doctor, Doc.
Our butts hurt.
Okay. Let's do this. And watch your droppings.
Tonight, this is the house of love! East Coast! West Coast! Let's unite! Is Brooklyn in the house...?

[John is acting as a marriage counsellor to a couple of pigeons]
... It's not something you should be ashamed of. It happens to most men occasionally. You're probably under a lot of pressure.

He's not under pressure. He's not atracted to me, because I'm just a pigeon. He's a self-hating pigeon... As him what he does all day... He sits in a tree by himself - because he's too good to eat with the rest of us, when the old people feed us in the park. And the way he stares at a robin's breasts, it's enough to make you sick.
I happen to be attracted to orange breasts.

[to her husband]
You're not a robin, or a dove, or a hawk. You're a pigeon, and I'm a pigeon...

[to John]
She sits on the nest all day and gets crazy.
...With three eggs, and they're gonna be pigeons, too.
[flies off]

[to John]
May I ask you something? If I turn THIS way, don't I look a LITTLE like a blue jay?
...You're suffering from obsessive-compulsive behavior...

[bouncing like a pogo stick]
Throw the ball!
When you want the ball, think about something else...
Don't say anything more! Throw the ball!
You need to relax your mind...

You're the person. You throw the ball. I'm the dog. I get it. Simple as that. I swear, I'll pee on your carpet. Please, please, please, throw the ball. Shut up and throw the ball. Am I alone here? Am I all by myself? Am I in ANOTHER UNIVERSE?
THROW THE DAMN BALL!
[John resignedly does so]
He threw the ball! Oh, he threw the ball! I'll get it! I'll get it! I love you! I love you! You threw the ball...!

[to John]
... You can't save 'em all, Hasselhoff.

[having shown himself to John's apartment]
... Is there a doctor in the house...? They're gonna kick me off the force. I'm as blind as a bat. Can you help me?
[and later, after John has corrected his vision]
... Holy road apples! I can see! No desk job for me! Thanks a million, Doc. This is gonna be great. I'll make lieutenant. Nothing can stop me, nothing - Look a that, a doughnut shop...!
corporate cars every two years.

[referring to how they've lost touch with what's really important]
Hey, Mark... Do you remember when we first started out? We had those crummy offices, at the worst neighborhood in town. We got paid almost no money.
I've blocked it out.

[having tracked John all the way to the Hammersmith Retreat]
... I crossed three freeways to get here - at NIGHT, no less - and all you can say is "What are you doing here?"

[to her dog]
Lie down, Chauncey. Lie down. Lie down, Chauncey!
[to John]
He's deaf.
I'm not deaf. I just can't stand listening to her.

[just hatched, looks at Rodney]
Mama?
Mama, I'm not ya mama.

[to Lucky]
Mama?
Oh, no, don't look at me... Well, there was this one time I got drunk in the Everglades...
How come I can hear you talking?
I dunno. Maybe you're just weird or something.
Shut up. You're a dog. DOGS CANNOT TALK.
What the hell do you think barking is, an involuntary spasm?
Hi, I'm Lucky! It works on two levels, I love it!
[after he starts hearing animal voices]
Those guys in my dorm told me that stuff wouldn't mess me up, now fifteen years later, this shit happens!
No! Don't fix me! DON'T fix me! I'll never look at another female ever, I swear! Just don't take my manhood, man! Anything but my ma...
[he sees a Lassie-esque border collie walk past]
Yo baby wassup, you lookin' pretty sweet there sugar.
I am Kyser Soze.
I have to interpret *why* the dog is whining. He can't tell me.
What's to tell? There's a thermometer! It's in my butt!

[Trying to keep the Tiger from jumping off a tower]
There's been plenty of great tigers.
Oh yeah? Name one
How about Tony?
Tony the cereal tiger?
Well I didn't hear you come up with anything.

[while John is operating on the tiger]
He still thinks he can talk to animals.
He can Lisa. He *can* talk to animals. It started when he was young. I thought it was a handicap. But it's a gift Lisa
Somebody get the license plate number. I have just been violated!
Need some help?
Oh, no, I'm - we're - we're fine. I'm just stretching my legs a little here.
Ask her if she's got any lettuce.
Shut your mouth. Shut your furry little mouth right now!
[first lines]

[narrating]
You know, they say the great thing about being a kid is, it's so easy to pretend. You can have a conversation with your dog or a baseball or a banana. Well, what if wasn't pretend? What if you could have a conversation. I mean, not with a baseball or a banana - that's ridiculous, but - but with your dog?
[last lines]
I want my own room, with a TV. Basic cable will be fine.
I hate stories with happy endings.
Yoo-hoo.
What did you say?
I didn't say nothing.
Then who?
[squawks and takes flight]
Ahhh! Run! Run for your lives! Oh my God! Let's go, buddy.
I don't want to die. I'm too young to die! Hang a left! No, hang a right! Look out for the traffic! Oh, legs, do your thing. Get out of my way!
This circle of life really stinks!

[after Dr. Dolittle hears him talk for the first time]
Okay, let's chill. Let's just chill.
I'm not gonna chill.
You gonna chill.
[Dr. Dolittle grabs his cage and removes it from the car]
Uh, what are you doing, switching sides?
She was my best friend.
You'll make some real friends now.

[narrating]
From that day on, John Dolittle never spoke to animals again.
Someday, you're gonna thank me for this.

[narrating]
And after a while, all he could remember was that deep down inside, there was something missing.

[John is about to operate on Jake, the tiger]
Have you ever done this operation before?
Yeah, once in medical school. But it was to a cadaver. But my professor told me I did such a good job that, had my patient not been dead, he would've lived.

[sarcastically]
Very comforting, Doc.
Hey, give me a break. I saved your life.
That's yesterday's news. Take a hike. You want gratitude? Get a hamster!
I just might hang myself by my underpants! I can get underpants! Well, not really.
Leave this boy, devil man! Go now, Satan, take the serpent's voices with ya! I command you to come out of this boy! Come on out of this boy! God said it! Come on out of this boy!

[regarding Rat #1]
You got to help him.
Oh, really? Why is that?
'Cause you're the man. You're the man.
Oh, I'm the man now. I thought I was the guy the other day that you wanted to get bubonic with.

[annoyed that Maya is pestering him about an egg]
I don't know what all the fuss is about. We went and bought you that thing anyway. You got a pet. What was that pet rat thing that we bought?
A guinea pig.
We got you the guinea rat, and the thing died. It's not our fault that it died.
It didn't die. His name is Rodney, and he's in my room.
So why are you bothering me about this swan? I'm going to work. I'm out of here. Good-bye.
